articles.headline: Retailers Push Fed for Yet Lower Debit Fees
articles.snippet: Trade groups representing retailers, convenience stores and grocers filed a lawsuit against the Federal Reserve, asserting that an additional variable fee violates the law.
articles.abstract: Trade groups representing retailers, convenience stores and grocers filed a lawsuit against the Federal Reserve, asserting that an additional variable fee violates the law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Retailers won a big victory last summer when the Federal Reserve halved the fees that banks and credit card companies were charging them to process debit card transactions.

articles.headline: A Question of Fairness
articles.snippet: Fair Trade USA, a leading advocate of the movement, said it would make far-reaching changes in the products that get its seal of approval. Critics accused it of watering down standards.
articles.abstract: Fair Trade USA, a leading advocate of the movement, said it would make far-reaching changes in the products that get its seal of approval. Critics accused it of watering down standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: A tempest in a coffee pot is bubbling in the world of “fair trade,” the socially responsible food movement that seeks to lift farmers in the developing world out of poverty by offering them a premium for crops like coffee, cocoa and bananas. And the fight will soon reach your local Starbucks, Wal-Mart and Whole Foods.

articles.headline: Weak Bond Sale Tests Germany’s Stature in Crisis
articles.snippet: An auction of German government bonds met slack demand, suggesting that investors are beginning to question whether there are any havens left in Europe.
articles.abstract: An auction of German government bonds met slack demand, suggesting that investors are beginning to question whether there are any havens left in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Germany’s stature as an island of stability in the European debt crisis was shaken Wednesday when it fell far short of selling all the government bonds it put up for auction.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Cameras Are Small, Quality Is Big
articles.snippet: Sony, Samsung and Canon introduced cameras that can produce the best possible photos from the smallest possible devices.
articles.abstract: Sony, Samsung and Canon introduced cameras that can produce the best possible photos from the smallest possible devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re an electronics fan, you have plenty to be grateful for at this year’s Thanksgiving dinner: The dawn of easy-to-use touch-screen gadgets. A sensible C.E.O. at Hewlett-Packard. Angry Birds.

articles.headline: Opening Day for Shoppers Shows Divide
articles.snippet: When stores open for Black Friday sales late Thursday night, the differences between how affluent and more ordinary Americans shop in the uncertain economy will be on unusually vivid display.
articles.abstract: When stores open for Black Friday sales late Thursday night, the differences between how affluent and more ordinary Americans shop in the uncertain economy will be on unusually vivid display.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the busiest retail weekend of the year begins late Thursday night, the differences between how affluent and more ordinary Americans shop in the uncertain economy will be on unusually vivid display.

articles.headline: First, He Blew the Whistle on Olympus. Next, He Wants to Lead Its Comeback.
articles.snippet: Michael Woodford, the former chief executive of Olympus, plans to return for a board meeting, and he said he would offer to return to the company as president.
articles.abstract: Michael Woodford, the former chief executive of Olympus, plans to return for a board meeting, and he said he would offer to return to the company as president.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Olympus fired Michael Woodford, its British chief executive, in October, the company said he had been unable to conform to Japanese-style management.

articles.headline: In This Town, Turkey Picks Up Bill for Dinner
articles.snippet: Workers at a Butterball plant in northwest Arkansas and at another factory nearby help produce about a third of the 43 million turkeys the nation will eat on Thanksgiving.
articles.abstract: Workers at a Butterball plant in northwest Arkansas and at another factory nearby help produce about a third of the 43 million turkeys the nation will eat on Thanksgiving.
articles.lead_paragraph: OZARK, Ark. — Brenda Farmer and Willie Blanscet have sat across from each other on the Butterball bagging line for 17 years, 102 cold, raw turkeys sliding by in front of them every minute.

articles.headline: Egypt Military and Protesters Dig In for a Long Standoff
articles.snippet: As clashes halted, Egypt’s military rulers vowed to forge ahead with parliamentary elections on Monday despite a week of violence that is certain to tarnish the vote.
articles.abstract: As clashes halted, Egypt’s military rulers vowed to forge ahead with parliamentary elections on Monday despite a week of violence that is certain to tarnish the vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s interim military rulers and the masses of protesters demanding their exit dug in Thursday for a prolonged standoff as the generals vowed to forge ahead with parliamentary elections despite a week of violence that is certain to tarnish the vote.

articles.headline: AT&T Merger With T-Mobile Faces Setbacks
articles.snippet: The companies said they had withdrawn their application to the F.C.C. to join their cellular phone operations but still plan to contest a federal antitrust lawsuit and pursue their $39 billion deal.
articles.abstract: The companies said they had withdrawn their application to the F.C.C. to join their cellular phone operations but still plan to contest a federal antitrust lawsuit and pursue their $39 billion deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — AT&T and T-Mobile USA edged closer to scrapping their proposed merger, saying on Thursday that they had withdrawn their application to the Federal Communications Commission to join their cellular phone operations.
articles.byline: By Edward Wyatt and Jenna Wortham
